messageBody:
Elliotte,

I have a patch that makes this work, but I don't like it very much. One of our philosophies in JUnit has been to make it more of the intersection of all testing tool functionality instead of the union. While I can imagine ignore() being sort of useful, especially now that we have @Ignore, it doesn't seem *that* useful to me. Perhaps I need to lower my "threshold of utility". What do you think? How about others--would ignore() be helpful to you?

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Elliotte Harold
> Sent: Thursday, September 22, 2005 8:49 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] JUnit 4 RFE: ignoring a test at runtime
>
> Some of my tests methods contain logic like this:
>
> XMLReader crimson;
> try {
> crimson = XMLReaderFactory.createXMLReader(
> "org.apache.crimson.parser.XMLReaderImpl");
> }
> catch (SAXException ex) {
> // can't test Crimson if you can't load it
> return;
> }
> // OK. We found Crimson. Now let's run the test
>
> In other words, I'm testing a workaround for a bug in a
> particular class
> that may or may not be present. Such tests might also depend on
> platform, java version, or other environmental conditions. In
> JUnit 3 if
> I can't really make the test due to environmental problems I
> only have
> two options: pass or fail. Neither is really satisfactory or properly
> explains what;s happening.
>
> In JUnit 4 we can annotate a test as @Ignore. However that's
> only good
> at compile time. What I want is an ignore() or skip() method
> similar to
> the fail() method. However this method signals that a test
> was skipped
> instead of failed. Is there such a method already? If not,
> could we have
> one please? I looked but I couldn't find one in the current
> code base,
> but then I just wasn't looking in the right place.
>
